conclusion: Understanding the problem setup with two hemispheres A and B, masses m and 2m, friction between A and left wall, and a 30-degree angle.
Two hemispheres between vertical walls, A on the left, B on the right, with a 130-degree angle in the image.
Assuming a 30-degree angle based on the problem description.
Line connecting centers of A and B makes a 30-degree angle with the horizontal, no friction between A and B, friction between A and left wall.
Need to draw free-body diagrams for A and B to understand forces.
Hemisphere B has mass 2m, weight 2mg downward, no friction between A and B.
Normal forces from A and right wall act on B.
Define N_AB as normal force from A on B, N_Bwall as normal force from right wall on B, F_fric_A as friction force between A and left wall, N_Awall as normal force from left wall on A.
Hemisphere A has mass m, weight mg downward, friction with left wall, normal force from B on A.
Consider forces in horizontal and vertical directions for A and B.
For hemisphere B, weight is 2mg downward, vertical components of normal forces from A and wall.
Resolve N_AB into horizontal and vertical components due to 30-degree angle.
Horizontal component of N_AB: N_AB * cos(30°), Vertical component of N_AB: N_AB * sin(30°).
Normal force from right wall is horizontal since wall is vertical.
Normal force between A and B is along the line connecting them at 30 degrees.
Consider centers of hemispheres as points to understand distances and apply force balances.
Assume hemispheres placed between vertical walls, A closer to left wall, B closer to right wall.
Find distances between walls and centers of A and B for force balances.
Consider forces on each hemisphere and set up equilibrium equations.
Balls are just about to slide, friction forces at maximum static values.
Maximum static friction equals sliding friction, which is μ times the normal force.
